name: Lucero Calderón

name: Cameron Frew
review: A spectacular, once-in-a-lifetime epic. Avengers, dismissed.

name: William Venegas
review: The film designs its moments wel. [Full review in Spanish]

name: Robert Horton

name: Ben Rolph

review: The most impressive aspect of what's sure to be one of the biggest blockbusters in history is how intimate and personal so much of the story is and how quieter character moments aren't lost in the shuffle.

name: Khal Davenport
review: "Speeches are given, battles are fought, jokes are thrown-many of them. In fact, they pack a LOT of funny into this three hours, for good or ill. In the end, the satisfaction of having stayed the course with Marvel is rewardedtenfold."

name: Mara Reinstein
review: Directors Anthony and Joe Russo have somehow crafted a coherent and exhilarating epic that incorporates all your favorite superheroes (and many of their loved ones) in one emotionally resonant package.

name: Travis Hopson
review: Marvel has built up an incredible amount of emotional currency and Endgame is a very satisfying payoff

name: Keith Uhlich
review: Every serious narrative beat in the film is ultimately undercut by pro-forma storytelling, or by faux-improvised humor.

name: Jeffrey Lyles
review: Delivers on all fronts with the most satisfying final acts I've ever seen. This was like a Thanos snap to my expectations and then some.

name: Robert Kojder
review: One word comes to mind, and it's a word that has never been associated with just about anything regarding the whole of the Marvel Cinematic Universe; finality

name: Dan Murrell
review: [Joe and Anthony Russo] take every cent of capital that these movies have earned over the last 11 years & spend it in the best, most economic way you could possibly imagine.

name: Robbie Collin
review: I can't recall a film in this cinematic universe or any other that works as relentlessly and ingeniously to keep delighting its audience than this.

name: Grace Randolph
review: Downright Spielberg-ian! A perfect way to cap off ten years of the MCU, and get audiences excited for the next ten.

name: Helen O'Hara
review: A victory lap that moonwalks through the best part of the MCU back catalogue and emphasises emotion as much as action, this is an intensely satisfying piece of blockbuster filmmaking.

name: Spencer Perry
review: The movie works because it delivers everything you want and all the things you didn't know you needed.

name: Dorian Parks
review: If you've invested years of your life to the MCU [Marvel Cinematic Universe] like I have, this movie will feel like a fan letter to you. Kevin Feige and his team deserve so much praise for being able to pull off something of this magnitude.

name: Eric Eisenberg
review: [O]ne of the most ambitious, entertaining, emotional, and stunning blockbusters we've ever seen, and the best film in the Marvel Cinematic Universe canon thus far.

name: Mark Daniell
review: We haven't seen anything like this before in franchise movie-making. One can only hope that the next 10 years of Marvel storytelling comes close to this.

name: Yago García
review: This decade with the costumed adventurers has been worth it. [Full Review in Spanish]

name: Eric Kohn
review: As "Endgame" sputters to the finish line, it leaves the impression of witnessing a Marvel Movie Marathon compressed to three hours - and 58 seconds, but trust me, they're disposable - of unbridled fan service.

name: Jason Gorber
review: Spectacle gives way to heroic journeys fulfilled, quests finally culminating and closure finally reached.

name: EJ Moreno
review: Rarely do event movies live up to the hype, but Avengers: Endgame shatters any expectations. A glorious superhero epic!

name: Nick Johnston
review: It's everything a fan could want.

name: John Tones
review: An undeniable triumph for Marvel and an essential appointment for fans of the genre. [Full Review in Spanish]

name: Brent Hankins
review: If Avengers Endgame -- with its carefully crafted emotional beats, thrilling action sequences and heartbreaking farewells to some of our most beloved heroes -- isn't the perfect final chapter, I can't imagine what perfection might look like.

name: Sean P. Means
review: "Avengers: Endgame" delivers everything Marvel fans will enjoy and not much that they expect.

name: Jake Coyle
review: More than any of those franchises, "Endgame," at its best moments, carries the thrill of classic comic-book twists and reversals.

name: Tania Lamb
review: Avengers: Endgame is a satisfying finale to the Marvel Cinematic Universe chapters we've watched and loved. This one may not be for small children, though, due to language and violence.

name: Anne Cohen
review: Endgame is truly a masterful piece of storytelling, which both goes exactly where you expect it to, and not at all.

name: Jamie Graham
review: Part of the journey is the end, and this goes out with a bang that'll make you whimper.

name: Don Kaye
review: A massive, incredibly entertaining epic that is as emotional as it is spectacular.

name: Alex Abad-Santos
review: The most shocking thing about Avengers: Endgame is that there are several moments within this colossal movie that feel like a Marvel miracle.

name: Susana Polo
review: Endgame knows what its audience wants, and delivers that without feeling like quote-unquote fan service.

name: Barry Hertz
review: [T]he entire endeavour loses any sense of emotional stakes or general meaning beyond the deliverance of crass fan-service and incomprehensible visuals.

name: Molly Freeman
review: Avengers: Endgame wraps up the story of the MCU so far, delivering an epic superhero adventure while honoring the past in a satisfying finale.

name: Brian Truitt
review: If the Marvel superhero movies on the whole are your favorite band's individual albums, "Avengers: Endgame" is the triple-disc greatest-hits package with the really awesome cover and a slew of familiar, comforting gems inside.

name: Gary Thompson
review: I wasn't sure, after the tedium of Infinity War, that Marvel could wrap this up in a satisfying way. Turns out, it was a snap.

name: J. Don Birnam
review: The longer run-time and bloated cast are surprising strengths, permitting this grand finale to be more than just a superhero flick. A fitting, over-arching conclusion by a studio that knows how to get this genre spot on.

name: Laura Prudom
review: A fitting and surprisingly poetic payoff to more than a decade of storytelling, and the start of a bright new chapter.

name: Angie Han
review: This is Marvel flexing, building on over 10 years and 20-plus films of careful groundwork and intricate planning to show us what it can do that no other movie franchise can. As such, it's an immensely satisfying finish to this era of the series.

name: Tom Fitzgerald and Lorenzo Marquez
review: Endgame is an extremely well-made film, helmed by two directors who knew exactly what they were doing the whole time.

name: Johnny Oleksinski
review: You have to hand it to the directors for their ambition in bringing together a clown car full of characters into such a well-told and compelling yarn.

name: Perri Nemiroff
review: Avengers: Endgame is a lot - sometimes too much. But, wow, the payoff is huge. It leaves you proud to have invested over a decade in a franchise that delivers an inspiring exploration of what it means to be family and a hero.

name: Michael Phillips
review: [E]xtravagant - and mostly very gratifying.

name: Robert Daniels
review: For now, the cast, crew, and creators of the past decade may rest easy on a sun-drench porch with the knowledge that [Endgame] accomplished their ultimate goal. For better or for worse.

name: David Sims
review: The Avengers, as a concept, probably won't be going anywhere, but Endgame still feels like a proper goodbye.

name: Chris Hunneysett
review: It's game over for Marvel's competition as their latest superhero spectacular smashes into cinemas like the Hulk on steroids, and is the thunderous triumph we've all been hoping for.

name: Thaddeus McCollum
review: For the most part, Endgame delivers on the unique brand of humor, action and drama that Marvel has down to a science at this point.

name: Brian Lowry
review: Having set up a formidable task and then some with the finish of "Infinity War," "Avengers: Endgame" rises to the challenge, delivering an epic finale that proves immensely satisfying.

name: A.O. Scott
review: At its best - and "Endgame" is in some ways as good as it gets - the "Avengers" cosmos has been an expansive and inclusive place.

name: Russ Fischer
review: Endgame reaches a conclusion that is not only spectacularly satisfying, but thematically powerful.

name: Leah Greenblatt
review: The movie largely delivers, splashing its ambitious three-hour narrative across a sprawling canvas of characters, eras, and not-quite-insurmountable challenges.

name: Rendy Jones
review: Emotionally epic in every sense of the word, Endgame is a satisfying conclusion to the MCU's 11-year conquest that delivers enough feels and action to cream your pants over.

name: Matt Goldberg
review: By carrying the weight of 21 movies with it, Endgame feels far grander, surprising, and emotional than your typical sequel.

name: Tessa Smith
review: Avengers: Endgame perfectly ties together the entire MCU. It has always been connected, but now it is complete. An emotional roller coaster I cannot wait to ride again.

name: Todd McCarthy
review: [W]hat comes across most strongly here, oddly enough for an effects-driven comic-book-derived film, is the character acting, especially from Downey, Ruffalo, Evans, Hemsworth, Brolin and Paul Rudd as Ant-Man.

name: Scott Davis
review: Avengers: Endgame goes galaxies beyond expectations and exceeds anything that any of us could have imagined. The perfect end to an incredible series of films.

name: Peter Bradshaw
review: I have to admit, in all its surreal grandiosity, in all its delirious absurdity, there is a huge sugar rush of excitement to this mighty finale, finally interchanging with euphoric emotion and allowing us to say poignant farewells.

name: Ashley Menzel
review: Our heroes are giving their final bow and it is a joy and pleasure to witness.

name: Peter Debruge
review: After the must-see showdown that was 'Infinity War,' the Russo brothers deliver a more fan-facing three-hour followup, rewarding loyalty to Marvel Cinematic Universe.

name: Alonso Duralde
review: Has almost nothing on its mind but crossing the Ts and dotting the Is of a far-flung superhero saga, but to anyone with even a minor emotional stake in the MCU, it has the fleeting satisfaction of a shot of whipped cream direct from the spray can.

name: Chris Evangelista
review: Ultimately, Avengers: Endgame feels exhausting. That's not a knock against the movie, though.

name: Germain Lussier
review: Avengers: Endgame is everything you've ever dreamed a Marvel movie could be. It's a three-hour adrenaline shot to the heart featuring mysteries solved, consequences suffered, shock, awe, and delight

name: Clint Worthington
review: Endgame is the best possible love letter to the MCU one could muster, a big, sloppy kiss to its fans and the characters that made these movies so appealing in the first place.

name: Matt Singer
review: A gargantuan love letter to Marvel's equally enormous mythology.

name: Justin Chang
review: To these faintly moistened eyes, "Avengers: Endgame" achieves and earns its climactic surge of feeling, even as it falls just short of real catharsis.

name: Charles Barfield
review: Avengers: Endgame is the triumphant crescendo to the biggest film journey that has ever graced cinemas. But casual fans need not apply.

name: Danielle Solzman
review: Marvel Studios' previous films have all been leading up to Avengers: Endgame and the film is very much worth the three-hour run time.

name: Joey Magidson
review: "Avengers: Endgame" brings the Marvel Cinematic Universe to a worthy conclusion, eliciting more emotion than any superhero film yet. I laughed, cried, and was filled with joy.

name: Christie Cronan
review: Avengers: Endgame is the realization that all of these Marvel movies are so much more than just 10+ years of entertainment - they're family.

name: Matthew Pejkovic
review: A grand, clever and heartfelt blockbuster sure to enthral its audience.

name: Jason Escamilla
review: If you're a Marvel fan, this film is made for you and you're going to love it!

name: Clayton Davis
review: Jeremy Renner's new haircut-having Hawkeye and Karen Gillan's Nebula are really (and finally?) given an opportunity to stretch their acting legs and it's a joy to see.

name: Donald Clarke
review: Endgame spends too much time wallowing in its own pompous mythology.

name: Lawrence Garcia
review: Tenet fails to convince as either dramatic or action spectacle, let alone as philosophical investigation ... [it's] a house of cards, built only to be toppled over.

name: Andrew Kendall
review: Even as Tenet engages in loads of hand-wringing about the implications the characters' actions have for the future, it's hard to really form any worry for that future that exists only in prolepsis.

name: Nick Levine
review: Though it's sometimes hamstrung by clumsy dialogue - a necessary evil, perhaps, given how much Nolan needs to explain - Tenet is rarely less than thrilling to watch.

name: Rhys Bowen Jones
review: Tenet is one of the most enthralling cinematic experiences I have had for years.

name: Jeffrey Overstreet
review: Exhausted and disoriented by Nolan's curlicue-rollercoasters, we end up fooled into thinking we've been stirred when, in fact, we've mostly been shaken.

name: Niall Browne
review: Christopher Nolan's Tenet is a film which can be enjoyed, but it's highly likely that you won't really understand it. It takes a lot of big ideas - and a lot of big moviemaking techniques to deliver a film which is mesmerising but very flawed.

name: David Walsh
review: It is not so much a matter of criticizing Nolan's filmmaking, which is not very difficult to do. The important issue is to understand and criticize the conditions that produced his filmmaking ...

name: Vincent Schilling
review: Led beautifully by protagonist John David Washington, 'Tenet', an exceptional action-packed film, dives into a concept of twisting time in a way never explored before. I'm adding this to my permanent library.

name: Tim Robey
review: As a delivery system for the thrills, I think the film gets a long way, and you can kind of sit back and enjoy it. As a delivery system for the ideas, I think it trips itself up an awful lot.

name: Pablo O. Scholz
review: [Has] perfectly orchestrated battle scenes. [Full review in Spanish]

name: Rob Gonsalves
review: It means what you want it to mean, and I don't want it to mean anything. It's just a ride.

name: Mark Meszoros
review: By the end of its two-and-a-half-hours, with all its bi-directional action, revelations and world-ending ramifications, it's a bit numbing, And you're pretty sure you can't wait to watch it again.

name: Eddie Harrison
review: ...a high-faluting, high energy, uber-glam espionage thriller...

name: Tony Black
review: Just go with it. Allow the inversion to pull you along because it does, for the most part, make sense by the end.

name: Alix Turner
review: Huge scale, gripping and ambitious sci-fi spy thriller from Christopher Nolan, which simply has to be seen to be believed, and possibly seen more than once to be fully appreciated.

name: Brian Gill
review: It's the most Nolan movie ever and I'm not sure it makes since but I was enthralled nonetheless.

name: Kathia Woods
review: The future is now or in the past

name: Alex Bentley
review: Nolan's obsession with making his films as complex as humanly possible is frustrating for those of us who would like at least a scintilla of clarity in our storytelling.

name: MaryAnn Johanson
review: Washington and Pattinson have palpable charisma, but this cold puzzle offers no incentive to solve it. Throw in damsel-in-distress crap, and both my geek sensibilities and my feminism are offended.

name: Nick Schager
review: Something like the epitome of [Nolan's] temporally twisty canon, distilling his many cinematic signatures and preoccupations down to their entrancing abstract essence.

name: PJ Nabarro
review: Nolan's reverence for tech and the cleverness of pulling off a metaphysical narrative puzzle finally swamps his awareness of whether the thing in question is even any good.

name: Richard Crouse
review: The trippy last hour is jam packed with artfully arranged action scenes that manipulate time in increasingly psychedelic ways.

name: Mark Cassidy
review: Tenet has its moments, but is easily Nolan's worst film. Mostly incomprehensible; this muddled sci-fi thriller is a long way from being the "savior of cinema." Honestly, it'd be difficult to recommend even if we weren't in the middle of a pandemic.

name: Sean Fennessey
review: Tenet asks for patience as it winds forward and backward through its narrative accordion structure...savor, even [its] flaws.

name: Joey Morona
review: ...'Tenet' makes 'Inception' feel like a children's story. The film is magnificently and perhaps quite purposefully confusing.

name: Luke Hicks
review: Tenet isn't here to collect Oscars. It exists to pummel you with excitement, twist your sense of reality, and leave you confounded with the deafening power of its nine-figure budget.

name: Matt Brunson
review: The weakest of Nolan's 11 cinematic at-bats to date, Tenet finds the filmmaker unable to get out of his own way as he attempts to spin a yarn that makes earlier efforts like Memento seem as linear and uncomplicated as A Charlie Brown Christmas.

name: Ben Kuchera
review: I love Tenet so much, despite its frustrations. Nolan wants to keep pushing the boundaries of these kinds of blockbusters, and that means he's going to fail as much as he succeeds.

name: Sheraz Farooqi
review: Tenet is a Christopher Nolan film in every way. An amalgamation of themes & threads out of his other films combined into one, Tenet has shades of Nolan's best work, but not without flaws.

name: Yasser Medina
review: A science fiction film in which Nolan builds, visually, a twisted and frenetic experience of international espionage that is structured as if it were a narrative palindrome of dualities and retrocausality. [Full review in Spanish]

name: Diana Mangas
review: It's an audiovisual experience that no movie lover should miss. Stimulating, revealing, adrenaline-pumping and spectacular, this is Christopher Nolan's new proposal. [Full review in Spanish]

name: Susan Granger
review: Visually dazzling but absolutely incomprehensible and impenetrable...

name: Nestor Bentancor
review: Less of a puzzle and more like a mechanical bull. But at home you can tame -and appreciate- this beast. [Full Review in Spanish]

name: Armond White
review: Fact is, Tenet should not be taken more seriously than a James Bond movie. As an action film, it isn't nearly as skillful as a Tom Cruise Mission Impossible commodity.

name: Grant Watson
review: It is an imperfect film, but to dismiss it would be to punish it for merely being 'good' and not 'great'.

name: Victor Pineyro
review: The film feels a lot like an allusion of its palindrome title. What I like most about Nolan, and Tenet, is that it challenges me and reminds me, forgive the redundancy, that movies are first felt and then understood. [Full review in Spanish]

name: Robert Roten
review: Even if you are confused by all this complexity, there is still much to enjoy here. For me, it was just too much. I prefer more character depth and less emphasis on manufactured plot complications.

name: Christopher Llewellyn Reed
review: Love your palindromes? The film is a dud.

name: Sarah Marrs
review: Anyone who insists Tenet is Important or Otherwise Notable is probably trying to sell you something.

name: Kent Garrison
review: Like with other Christopher Nolan films, it will take multiple viewings to fully realize the scope of Tenet's groundbreaking accomplishments.

name: Daniel M. Kimmel
review: If you stick it out to the end, you'll either hate it or feel you need to watch it again.

name: Jim Ross
review: TENET ends up something of a Rube Goldberg machine of a film: a wondrously complex set of mechanics that is fascinating, but also an incredibly convoluted way of masking what is, in essence, a thin and poorly executed story.

name: Fico Cangiano
review: Christopher Nolan's most ambitious and complex film to date, also ends up being his most cold and lacking emotion. Not all of it works, but it's still better than many of the other releases this year. [Full review in Spanish]

name: Joel Mayward
review: "Tenet" succeeds in somehow transcending the audience's basic understanding of time and narrative while nevertheless keeping them engaged and entertained for the film's entirety.

name: John Serba
review: A Christopher Nolan movie is an event, and Tenet and its extraordinary action set pieces justify such a tag.

name: Frank Swietek
review: A flashy disappointment-intricate but not especially involving, clever but never captivating...a sterile exercise in spy movie cliché, with a twist that allows for some striking effects but... proves far less engaging than Nolan thinks it is.

name: Juan Barquin
review: Amid all the nonsensical writing, messy action, and blank characters, Tenet is a display of the pure, unfiltered blockbuster-filmmaking sensibilities that Nolan always delivers.

name: Tim Cogshell
review: [Christopher Nolan] is very clever, but mostly irritating is what I find. [His movies] are not cerebral - they're fake cerebral... He doesn't even do the time travel right.

name: Christy Lemire
review: I am a big fan of [Christopher Nolan's] films -- I usually enjoy the time puzzle of it -- but this seems even more intentionally inaccessible and challenging than everything else... Confusing, distancing, and chilly.

name: Daniel Barnes
review: Nolan at his most thrilling and semi-comprehensible.

name: Jared Mobarak
review: [We] get the full Nolan treatment in spectacle without [any] emotional and psychological lifting. It'll never [match] his best, but it's undeniably entertaining nonetheless.

name: Ryan Syrek
review: From Tenet's opening sequence to the final climactic battle, not knowing exactly what the hell is going on has never been so fun! That's actually kinda sincere...

name: Achara Kirk
review: I could see the points when the movie was like: this is the moment where I want you to have that emotional feeling, and I really wanted to get there... there wasn't enough done in the build-up of this whole movie for me to actually, really care.

name: Jaby Koay
review: It didn't engage with me as a viewer... the biggest reason I can see is that the main character didn't have this goal that was recognizable.

name: Jeffrey M. Anderson
review: 'Tenet' may contain [Nolan's] most ambitious use of time, but also, ultimately, the least effective.

name: Sean Burns
review: Garbled nonsense of a most entertaining order, it's basically a Christopher Nolan fetish film.

name: G. Allen Johnson
review: "Tenet" is indeed impressive, although I gave up trying to follow the plot.

name: Mick LaSalle
review: "Tenet" is difficult to understand, but even worse, it inspires little desire to understand it.

name: Devesh Sharma
review: All-in-all, much like the film's subject, Tenet is a film way ahead of its time. It's Nolan's most audacious experiment. Whether posterity favours it kindly -- only time will tell...

name: Chris Agar
review: Tenet﻿ is a fascinating and exciting sci-fi thriller bolstered by Nolan's grand vision for action and strong performances from the cast.

name: Allison Rose
review: Washington is decent as the Protagonist but not as good as he was as Ron Stallworth in BlacKkKlansman.

name: Mario Alegre
review: "Tenet" squanders all its visual spectacle through obtuse storytelling and dramatic inertia. [Full Review in Spanish]

name: Edwin Arnaudin
review: The convoluted logic begins to detract from the film's enjoyment - or it would if Nolan didn't keep tossing out exciting visuals to keep viewers engaged and challenged.

name: Mike McGranaghan
review: Tenet is Christopher Nolan's weakest film. It's also evidence that Christopher Nolan's weakest film is still way better and more exciting than some directors' best films.

name: Tessa Smith
review: The story & plot are super intriguing and quite clever. Once you hit the end of the film, it's all tied up in a neat little bow, proving itself to be more than worth a watch.

name: Filipe Freitas
review: ... mediocre espionage sci-fi thriller.

name: Douglas Davidson
review: ... Tenet is not the best film Nolan's created, but it may be his most ambitious and there's much to be lauded in that.

name: Joey Magidson
review: Tenet will go down as middle of the road Christopher Nolan. It's not a masterpiece and it's not a misfire.

name: Fred Topel
review: It's basically Inception for time travel instead of dreams.

name: Danielle Solzman
review: The best way to go about trying to understand Tenet is to just sit there and enjoy the ride.

name: Prahlad Srihari
review: If Tenet were a Beatles song, it would be Revolution 9: gun shots and car crashes, breaking glass and muffled words, all come together in a mix, made all the more unintelligible by segments happening forward and backward.

name: Rohan Naahar
review: To be constantly told how Tenet's engine works is like having Peter Jackson explain the metallurgy behind the One Ring -- unnecessary.

name: Emmanuel Báez
review: A well-oiled machine in which each element fulfills a specific function, and like all machinery, lacks a soul... Nonetheless, Tenet is a fascinating experience. [Full review in Spanish]

name: Charles Koplinski
review: Christopher Nolan's latest mindbender contains his trademark elaborate set pieces but lacks a story that makes a lick of sense.

name: Jim Schembri
review: A beautiful mess.

name: Ross Anthony
review: Excellent hard-hitting big-budget action, inconsistent dialogue /acting, refreshingly clever brain-stretching plot, great sound, a tad longer than necessary. Prepare to be confused, but entertained!

name: Tony Baker
review: I was confused... but it was well executed, well acted. It looked fantastic. The set pieces, the originality of the story was great.

name: Marie Asner
review: A film that wends its way around time, backward and forward, needs some space, and filling it with more intricacy doesn't always work.

name: Israel Acosta Aroche
review: For the first time in a long time Christopher Nolan's work just gets a bit tiring and tiresome as he exploits his obsession with time yet again in a way that's more noisy than expressive. [Full Review in Spanish]

name: Hugo Hernández Valdivia
review: An interesting palindrome, but really doesn't amount to anything significant. [Full Review in Spanish]

name: Robert Slack
review: Tenet is a heck of an achievement and is spectacular to watch. Technologically there is nothing like it.

name: Nathan Mattise
review: Tenet is the kind of movie that leaves you asking, "Why can't we have John David Washington as James Bond?"

name: Julio Fernando Navas
review: A cerebral thriller that gives us the most gimmicky version of Nolan we've seen yet. [Full review in spanish]

name: Matthew Pejkovic
review: Grand scale cinema fuelled by big ideas is undercut by frustratingly poor storytelling and a dull lead performance by John David Washington.

name: Matthew Lucas
review: An often electrifying grand scale thriller that tackles bold structural concepts, but its execution is a decidedly mixed bag.

name: Tom Santilli
review: When put in context of what we have come to expect from Christopher Nolan...Tenet seems to land with an even more despondent, painful thud.

name: Sebastian Zavala Kahn
review: It's the Nolanest movie that ever Nolaned, for better and for worse, and even more so than any of his previous efforts.

name: Kevin A. Ranson
review: ... asks viewers to trust what's going on will make sense once it reveals its secret... one of those rare instances where seeing the film more than once actually reaps a reward...

name: Rafael Motamayor
review: Alas, Tenet is 100% Christopher Nolan - for better and worse.

name: Eli Glasner
review: Some films grow richer with each viewing, I fear this one will fade. Best thing I can do is quote one of the time inversion scientists..."don't try to understand it."

name: Kelley Dong
review: The scale of its spectacle suggests innovation; but Nolan's combination of the reverse motion with the cross cut, which he's dressed with trivial exposition, has all been done before.

name: Jose Maria Areste
review: As if you were holding a Rubik's cube: you will not feel calm until you manage to solve it with your hands.

name: Damien Straker
review: An incomprehensible and pretentious misfire from the usually reliable Christopher Nolan.

name: Bob Grimm
review: Typically good Nolan puzzler.

name: Germain Lussier
review: That's Tenet in a nutshell. A movie obviously built on interesting, complex ideas, but with no clue how to put them into practice.

name: John Nguyen
review: Tenet shines with its action sequences and the time inversion premise, but it quickly wears out its welcome.

name: Shawn Edwards
review: John David Washington is the best part of Tenet...stuck in a story that makes zero sense and requires a massive amounts of Advil...

name: Dan Tabor
review: Dense and pretentious, Tenet will irritate even the most dedicated Nolan fans with its curiously flawed similarities to Inception.

name: Chris McCoy
review: Tenet addresses some important themes, such as the dangers of technology concentrating world-shattering powers in the hands of unaccountable individuals, but it treats the world as an abstraction of physics, not as a real place where real people live.

name: Rene Sanchez
review: Ambitious and grandiloquent, Tenet is a palindromic thriller where past and present converge in a mission against the clock. [Full Review in Spanish]

name: Kathleen Sachs
review: The auteur doesn't show much growth in his most recent self-indulgent work.

name: John McDonald
review: I doubt that even the director could explain what it's about.

name: Margot Harrison
review: Watching Tenet is like watching somebody else play a video game whose maddeningly complex rules you haven't had a chance to learn.

name: Colby Bryant
review: ...Even as it fumbles in key ways, TENET will fit the expectations set by most Nolan fans... even while this proves to be one of Nolan's lesser films, in my opinion.

name: Rendy Jones
review: There comes a point where Nolan's attention to detail as a visionary filmmaker fails to compensate for his current lack of storytelling abilities.

name: Kiko Martinez
review: As stellar as Tenet is for the senses, it is not something most moviegoers will want to revisit - unless, of course, they believe Nolan's brand of storytelling really doesn't add up until the third or fourth viewing.

name: Jackie K. Cooper
review: The dialogue was a little lame. Kenneth Branagh chewed the scenery. Elizabeth Debicki made no impact. But lordy, lordy no one can put a movie together like Christopher Nolan.

name: Rubén Rosario
review: With such lofty goals, the characters are reduced to pieces on a sleek chess board. And if Nolan doesn't give a damn about what happens to his chronology-challenged travelers, why should we?

name: Garth Franklin
review: The cast are solid talents, but all struggle to breath life into a film already overstuffed and whittled down to the point of leaving no time for any natural humanity to flow though it.

name: Anna Smith
review: It is easy to sit back and revel in the wonder of the big-screen experience, and to immediately want to see the film again. And again.

name: Ruth Maramis
review: While I think Nolan is a talented & visionary filmmaker, with TENET he seems to care more about the fantastical spectacle + time inversion extravaganza than he is about an affecting story, so the result frankly, is a cold, detached film.

name: Karen M. Peterson
review: It would be easy to dismiss the plot as confusing, but that would be generous.

name: Nicolás Ruiz
review: Tenet is an obnoxious, cold and unpleasant movie. Nevertheless, Nolan achieved a rare formal experiment never seen before in summer blockbusters. Hollow, cynic and revolutionary at the same time. [Full review in Spanish]

name: Tom Meek
review: This being a Christopher Nolan film, seeing it on a big screen is kind of a must - in the very least for the imposing, driving score [by Ludwig Göransson] and the impressive camera work by Hoyte Van Hoytema.

name: Brett McCracken
review: The real "inversion" of Tenet-and ultimately, all of Nolan's films-is that its stretching upward toward the heavens boomerangs back to this world.

name: Louisa Moore

name: Ruben Peralta Rigaud
review: The wait has been worth it. [Full review in Spanish]

name: Linda Cook
review: Mind. Officially. Blown.

name: Dennis Schwartz

name: Anthony Lane

review: A dazzling, confusing spectacle.

name: Tom Shone
review: In short, Tenet isn't any old Christopher Nolan movie. It's a Christopher Nolan movie squared - Nolan to the power of Nolan.

name: Simran Hans
review: Nolan seems to be... encouraging the audience to trust the film's beats and to feel its impact on a gut level. As a strategy of film-making, it's a supremely confident one and in parts Nolan pulls it off.

name: Emma Simmonds
review: Although shaky in its communication of the science, it more than makes up for it in ambition and stupendous action.

name: Doug Jamieson
review: It's easy to be dazzled by its visual feats, but it's hard to truly enjoy a film that leaves its audience feeling entirely befuddled and exhausted by everything they've just experienced.

name: Chris Hunneysett
review: bold, epic and ingenious

name: Tero Heikkinen
review: Washington in the lead is perfect and as we already saw in Spike Lee's BlacKkKlansman, he can carry a film on his shoulders. In Tenet this is even more evident.

name: Andrew F. Peirce
review: Tenet instead feels like it's pushing you away from engaging with its deeper plot, rather than inviting you in to engage with it intimately.

name: Anthony O'Connor
review: Overlong, noisy, full of poe-faced delivery of portentous dialogue, needlessly convoluted plot threads, unearned sense of gravitas that verges on the unintentionally hilarious and a script that isn't even vaguely as clever as it seems to think it is

name: Wenlei Ma
review: If Tenet had paid as much attention to its writing and character work as it did to its visual and conceptual ambitions, it could have been a masterpiece instead of merely great. But it's still great.

name: Philip De Semlyen
review: After five months stuck in front of the small screen, maybe being a little overwhelmed is no bad thing. But it's hard to escape the sense that less might have been more.

name: Peter Gray
review: It's breathtaking at times, and frustrating at others, but even with all its near-detrimental ambition it's a film that is at least trying to break a familiar mould.

name: Jamie East
review: It's a tense, bewildering assault on the senses. It was never going to live up to all the expectations - but despite the frayed plot and bad script, this is still a film you need to see.

name: Alan Corr
review: It's a high concept thriller which never fails to take itself with deadly seriousness but Tenet fails to live up to the intriguing set-up in the first act and doesn't quite convince the viewer of its internal logic...

name: Sandra Hall
review: No doubt avid students of the Nolan formula will get months of entertainment out of repeated viewings, but for me it was oddly tantalizing -- full of good things but ultimately frustrating.

name: Emily Zemler
review: Nolan is the sort of filmmaker who captures our imaginations for what could be possible, which is something that feels important right now.

name: Tom Beasley
review: If a headache can ever be pleasurable, it's when watching Tenet.

name: Danny Leigh
review: Great movies always time travel - living with you beyond the closing credits, carried into the future. With Tenet, 150 minutes pass harmlessly, but the film left my head before I took off my face mask.

name: Adam Woodward
review: If Nolan has out-Nolaned himself, it's in the action set-pieces which, despite being of head-scrambling technical intricacy, are sharper than Occam's razor and carried off with astonishing economy.

name: Scott Davis
review: Nolan is an artist extraordinaire.

name: Rosie Fletcher
review: The most important film of the year is a heavy weight to carry, and Tenet for the most part pulls it off. This may not be a perfect film but it could just be perfect cinema.

name: Leslie Felperin
review: Altogether, it makes for a chilly, cerebral film - easy to admire, especially since it's so rich in audacity and originality, but almost impossible to love, lacking as it is in a certain humanity.

name: Charlotte O'Sullivan
review: To point out that Tenet has flaws feels ungrateful. It's like slagging off Santa. But, I confess, some of the yick yacking - vis a vis physics, metaphysics and so on - made me sleepy... Those quibbles aside, Tenet is an eye-popping, ground-breaking blast.

name: Barry Hertz
review: We're never meant to know what exactly is going on at any one moment, but we will be - we must be - entertained by the overwhelming nonsense of it all.

name: Kevin Maher
review: The real joy of the film, nonetheless, is the sheer spectacle.

name: Radheyan Simonpillai
review: The movie is a race against a clock that defies everything we know about time. Massively scaled sequences have time moving forward and backwards and zigzagging all at once. The action exceeds anything Nolan has ever done before.

name: Linda Marric
review: Revisiting ideas he had already broached in his brilliantly underrated space saga Interstellar, Nolan is back again to his favourite subject, Time. The results are, unsurprisingly, phenomenal.

name: Jessica Kiang
review: Seek it out, if only to marvel at the entertainingly inane glory of what we once had and are in danger of never having again.

name: Matt Purslow
review: Tenet feels a little conservative, as if Nolan's style is a franchise rather than a framework. Despite this, it remains more interesting than most other tentpole movies and acts as a beacon for the director's strengths.

name: Fionnuala Halligan
review: It's a dream ride... for the most part, for anyone looking for glitzy escapism, and who wouldn't include themselves in that demographic right now.

name: Jonathan Romney
review: Nolan's latest may well be full of sound and fury, signifying nothing, or it may signify something imponderably resonant, and signify it forward, backward and inside out. Does your head hurt yet?

name: Shannon Connellan
review: It's the kind of film worthy of heralding a triumphant, unashamedly explosive return to cinemas, whenever that happens.

name: Andy Lea
review: Bamboozling, bold, wildly spectacular - this could be the perfect curtain-raiser for this year's delayed blockbuster season.

name: Catherine Shoard
review: The world is more than ready for a fabulous blockbuster... It's a real shame Tenet isn't it.

name: Mike McCahill
review: What's really there to untangle, beyond loops of string and a whole lot of smoke rings?

name: Brian Lloyd
review: When you come right down to it, 'Tenet' is a mess. A gloriously shot, exquisitely staged mess with a thrilling final act - but still a mess.

name: Simon Miraudo
review: For those who don't want to engage with Nolan's academic exercises, just tune out and revel in its baser pleasures: thrilling spy set pieces and charismatic leads. The other stuff? Ain't nobody got time for that.

name: Nicholas Barber
review: In the end, "Tenet" isn't one of Nolan's most satisfying films. But after I've seen it four or five more times, maybe I'll change my mind.

name: James Mottram
review: Happily, Tenet exceeds our already sky-high expectations.

name: Clarisse Loughrey
review: Tenet is a thrilling place to get lost in.

name: Jordan Farley
review: The stakes have never been higher, but Tenet is exactly the film cinemas need right now.

name: Donald Clarke
review: Even if we were brave enough to try, we would not be capable of spoiling a plot so wilfully obtuse it demands repeat viewings to disentangle.

name: Laura Potier
review: Tenet is technically excellent and challenging, pushing boundaries and subverting expectations with the director's usual elegance.

name: Guy Lodge
review: A concrete cornucopia of global chaos and threat, in which humanity's survival depends on the minor matter of reshaping time and space, "Tenet" looks well suited to an anxious age.

name: Alex Godfrey
review: By the time it's done, you might not know what the hell's gone on, but it is exciting nevertheless. It is ferociously entertaining.

name: Casey Chong
review: For all the technical achievements and Christopher Nolan's potentially captivating time-inversion concept, "Tenet" lacks the heart and soul to qualify as among the best movies in his illustrious filmography.

name: Ian Sandwell
review: An original and mind-bending take on a spy movie... Solely in terms of technical aspects, it's an incredible feat of filmmaking.

name: Jason Gorber
review: Say what you will about the tenets of TENET, at least it has an ethos.

name: Robert Daniels
review: Parabellum marks the most diverse entry into the John Wick franchise yet.

name: Fletcher Powell
review: You're clearly supposed to enjoy all the murder ... But I mostly just felt sad.

name: Richard Crouse

name: Mike Massie

name: Charles Koplinski
review: The gloriously rendered mayhem continues with this third entry in the series.

name: Tom Beasley
review: To call this a high-octane actioner is an understatement so stark it's like saying Mel Gibson is slightly problematic.

name: Steven Prokopy

name: Matt Cipolla

name: James Hanton
review: This is full-blooded cinema realising its full potential, with an entertaining internal logic, stunning setting and set pieces to die for.

name: Jason Fraley

name: Scott Phillips
review: It's a spectacle. Nothing more; nothing less. And that's enough.

name: Allen Almachar
review: You want to know if John Wick is back? Yeah, I think he's back.

name: Nabila Hatimy

name: Damond Fudge
review: Parabellum is exactly what you want in both a summer action film and a John Wick film. It's also the beginning of the series' gradual accent into controlled ridiculousness, the same fantastic way that the Fast & Furious franchise did.

name: Yasser Medina

name: David G. Hughes

name: Dan Tabor

name: Steven Sheehan
review: if you haven't got battle fatigue by the end you should prepare to suit up, reload and get ready to go out blazing.

name: Robert Roten

name: Ryan Silberstein
review: If you're the kind of person who can cheer when a knife toss is expertly executed, Chapter 3 should not be missed.

name: Dennis Schwartz
review: "It should have little appeal to viewers who want a film to make at least some sense and not be ultra-violent.

name: Damian Levy
review: The film-makers have managed to capture the lightning back in the bottle

name: Jennie Kermode
review: This is strictly a film for action fans. It has very little else to offer, but that doesn't much matter, because it's very good at what it does.

name: Neil Morris
review: The R-rated choreographed chaos remains the star of the series ... That said, the sumptuous, inventive Wick-verse is starting to show its stitching.

name: Paul McGuire Grimes

review: Director Chad Stahelski knows how to stage action, in this movie, he learns how to capture it.

name: Ian Thomas Malone
review: Parabellum ups the ante in a good way, an action-packed adventure bolstered by Reeves' dedication to his craft.

name: Dominic Griffin
review: We may not have gotten the John Wick sequel we wanted, but it's entirely possible it's the one we need for now.

name: Sean Chandler

name: Harris Dang

name: Pete Vonder Haar

name: Federico Furzan

name: Mahmoud Mahdy
review: I think by now it's safe to say that John Wick films are the standard setting products for the entire genre

name: Wenlei Ma

name: Filipe Freitas
review: Keanu Reeves embraces the title character with no smiles in a hectic performance at the physical level, but pretty relaxed in terms of lines.

name: David Nusair

name: Matt Hudson

name: Michael Sragow

name: Linda Cook
review: The third installment is violently entertaining.

name: Víctor López G.
review: I can only ask one question: When is the next one coming? [Full Review in Spanish]

review: [The] stars seem to be having a great time, from Anjelica Huston to an Asia Kate Dillon. [Full review in Spanish]

review: The Baba Yaga still stands in an entertaining film. [Full Review in Spanish]
