review: It's an excellent, bone breaking addition to John Wick's quest building a momentum I hope is carried in to the next chapters.

name: Matthew Bond
review: Same old, same old, some will say; after all, this franchise has always been violent and is clearly not about to change given that the sequel's Latin subtitle translates as 'prepare for war'.

name: Louise Keller
review: Visually striking with choreographed action that is as deadly as it is dazzling, John Wick: Chapter 3 Parabellum is inventive, creative and hits every mark within its sublime production design.... Keanu is at the top of his game...

name: Don Shanahan
review: Swelling enough from its redundancies, this symphony of gunpowder and gumption will satiate your summer thrills just fine.

name: Sarah Knight Adamson
review: Halle Berry's feisty character (Sofia) is a welcome breath of fresh air.

name: Susan Granger
review: An exaggerated, escapist, super-macho threequel - filled with ultra-violent action...

name: Tim Brennan
review: Strip away the guns, blades, and mayhem, and John Wick: Chapter 3 - Parabellum feels like an opera, myth, or folk tale. Heightened themes, a story told through violence, and a man forced to confront what he truly is.

name: Sarah Gopaul
review: Where this movie lacks finesse, it replaces it with brute force.

name: Jim Schembri
review: Fans of the first two Wick epics will have no complaints, thanks to the action being as superbly mounted and the sparks of humour being as straight-faced.

name: Matthew Dougherty
review: It's madly entertaining, and yet, the series still feels just a little bit afraid to indulge itself.

name: Wendy Ide
review: The latest instalment of John Wick makes an art of pain in a way that is curiously life-affirming.

name: Asher Luberto
review: In a world where the bad guys are doing the shootings, it's nice to see a good guy return the favor.

name: David Crow
review: John Wick continues in spectacular stunt sequences with increasingly tenuous logic. Part of that is appealing, but these days I would settle to see what an off-day for him at the dog park would look like.

name: Courtney Small
review: Stahelski pushes the boundaries of action to exciting new heights.

name: Rob Hunter
review: Keanu Reeves and company perform cinematic miracles once again.

name: Joe Friar
review: Reeves and Stahelski reunite for the most violent film in the franchise filled with breathtaking fight sequences that will leave you craving more.

name: Matt Ward
review: For a franchise designed to be a vehicle to watch anonymous bad guys die in creative ways, Parabellum is a huge success.

name: Bill Watters
review: Parabellum is a movie that knows itself, and what an audience wants out of it. As such, it delivers the goods while dialing the headshots to 11 (and maybe even 12).

name: Mike McGranaghan
review: Keanu is great, the action is stunningly staged, and the newcomers help to liven everything up.

name: Sergio López Aguirre
review: With each film, the John Wick franchise confirms that Keanu Reeves is one of the most bankable action stars of the moment. [Full Review in Spanish]

name: Josh Terry
review: The result is a film that is well-executed (sorry, pun intended), but that I feel uneasy enjoying or recommending.

name: S. Indra Sathiabalan
review: This movie may lack the brilliant premise of the first, but fans who can't get enough of Reeves will not be disappointed.

name: Rich Cline
review: In the final stretch, it begins to feel slightly stale, as if director Chad Stahelski was as bruised as his seemingly indestructible hero. But audiences will enjoy his audacious visual flourishes.

name: Rubén Rosario
review: The best movie the genre has seen since Mad Max: Fury Road is waiting to give you that unfiltered high that you crave. Is it too much of a good thing? At times, yes, but why would you want restraint from such a wild ride? In this case, too much is enough.

name: Kevin Maher
review: Choreography is all that's on offer here. The increasingly convoluted fight scenes turn into lifeless spectacle in this ugly franchise.

name: Daniel M. Kimmel
review: It's not clear if [there's] if they'll just play it out until Reeves or audiences get bored. Until then, no one is likely to be bored with John Wick: Chapter 3.

name: Chris Stuckmann
review: You have to hand it to them, giving it their all in these sequences...this is a great action achievement.

name: Rob Dean
review: A thrilling and clever film that seems bound only by the imagination of its filmmakers and the amount of punishment Reeves is able to handle.

name: Ben Sachs
review: Superior exercises in action-movie formalism, the John Wick movies evoke everything from Fritz Lang's silent thrillers to Gene Kelly's musicals...

name: Randall King
review: John Wick Chapter 3: Parabellum sees the franchise running out of steam as definitively as the exhausted, wounded Wick himself.

name: Annlee Ellingson
review: The creativity -- and sheer volume -- of killing in John Wick: Chapter 3 - Parabellum is breathtaking.

name: Adam Sweeting
review: Wick fans will adore this.

name: Dante James
review: It checks all the boxes you want in a fun, summer action film while not insulting your intelligence.

name: David 'Mad Dog' Bradley
review: Although such testosterone-dripping nonsense seems beyond criticism, there is always that nagging problem with these Wick epics where the dour, po-faced seriousness of tone sits ill with the messily black-comic gruesomeness...

name: Dann Gire
review: It sucks the air out of your lungs just thinking about how the filmmakers will top this.

name: Eric D. Snider
review: It is the battles for which this franchise exists, and Stahelski and his crew deliver an almost relentless series of epic ones, filmed and edited in such a way as to spotlight the skill of the performers.

name: Neil Soans
review: Parabellum is an essential entry to this series and one that cannot be missed.

name: Norman Wilner
review: The John Wick series turned into a video game so gradually we almost didn't notice; insert 15 bucks to continue.

name: Rashid Irani
review: Fasten your seatbelts and get set to savour the all-in-good-fun...

name: Sandy Schaefer
review: Character 3 - Parabellum offers enough dynamic set pieces and dazzling fight choreography to offset its flaws as a continuation of John Wick's story.

name: Jeffrey M. Anderson
review: Stahelski, a former stuntman, knows how to stage fights, but unlike most stuntmen, he knows how to film them, too, with clean, graceful camera moves, head-to-toe framing, and very few cuts, like a Fred Astaire/Ginger Rogers musical number.

name: Katherine Monk
review: Sure, there's a howling gale of action sequences and an acrobatic collage of mind-bending stunt work.. but really John Wick is about Keanu's chemistry with canines.

name: Rob Thomas
review: Keanu Reeves remains a magnetic centrifugal force in the midst of all the mayhem, the calm eye of a storm of blood spatters and broken bones.

name: Lindsey Romain
review: John Wick 3 builds on the impressive mythology of the first two films in new, beautiful, and often haunting ways.

name: Stephen Silver
review: What's great about this film, and the series overall, is that the action is so well-executed.

name: Robert Denerstein
review: Directed by Chad Stahelski, Chapter 3 skillfully spreads two hours and 10 minutes of choreographed violence across the screen...

name: George M. Thomas
review: A thrilling popcorn flick worthy of a look.

name: Abigail Camarillo
review: Will keep you on the edge of your seat. [Full review in Spanish]

name: Anne Brodie
review: I wanted to love this film because John Wick rules, but its heart is dead, slashed, shot, beaten, broken, smothered, run over and sabred, like most of the cast.

name: Reginald Ponder
review: The wick has been lit on both ends & it is getting hot! A non-stop action thriller that has so many kills that will surprise or just make you cheer. Reeves delivers Thrills, Kills and Chills!

name: Kate Sánchez
review: John Wick: Chapter 3...sets the bar for all action films to come after it. The revitalization of the genre is set squarely on the back of Reeves as an action star and Stahelski as a director who knows how to...create visual symphonies...

name: Jamie Dunn
review: Chapter 3 is relentless, only letting up for a few seconds to let you laugh at the absurdity and invention of its latest piece of ultraviolence.

name: Alci Rengifo
review: Parabellum is not only a worthy sequel to the last two John Wick films, it surpasses them.

name: Dwight Brown
review: The action in this crazed ode to human destruction, whether it's on horseback or motorcycles or in a hotel or souk, is some of the most mind-boggling and kinetic that's ever been displayed on-screen.

name: Piers Marchant
review: At its best, the [John] Wick films offer a visual, violent fantasia, with the indefatigable Wick dispatching hitman after hitman in often comically creative ways.

name: Matthew Lickona
review: It's rather like when Bond films went from Sean Connery to Roger Moore. Plenty of people will find this copacetic. A few will grouse about what's been lost: a touch of the real amid the merely fantastic.

name: Adam Graham
review: [I]t's a fun, entertaining romp that knows it's ridiculous from the moment that Wick takes out a towering 7-footer (the Philadelphia 76ers' Boban Marjanović) by beating him to death in a library with a book.

name: Matthew Razak
review: Is it up to the same quality and awesome of the first two? As our often monosyllabic and monotone hero would say in pitch-perfect understatement: yea.

name: Nick Rogers
review: The first half is fulsome in its fury, with Wick at his most improvisational and the series at its most ingenious and invigorating. The rest is ultimately a bit more enervating than you'd hope, but you remain invigorated by where the saga could go.

name: Alan Jones
review: The third in the endearingly violent thriller series that reinvented Keanu Reeves as a stoic hitman on a perpetual mission is easily the best.

name: Alan Zilberman
review: The sheer variety of brutal violence will have audiences cheer or wince in perfect harmony.

name: Phil Villarreal
review: This is a movie comfortable in its own goofy skin, and it's an unadulterated thrill to experience from beginning to end.

name: Robert Horton
review: I've always liked the fact that Reeves doesn't look like he pumps a lot of iron to get into the role; it makes John Wick's skill-set all the more otherworldly.

name: Armond White
review: [Director Chad] Stahelski knows there's pleasure in movie kinetics. The sheer nerve of the relentless fight scenes is hilarious, and their proficiency is cinematically gratifying. Parabellum lifts him to action-movie heights.

name: Gary Wolcott
review: I lost count of the body count very quickly. Just know it's over 100. Bloody, brutal and this year's top guilty pleasure movie.

name: Andrew Wyatt
review: Provided the series remains this exciting, inventive, and visually invigorating, anyone who appreciates the sweet science of cinematic violence should welcome a new John Wick film.

name: Kurt Loder
review: Wick 3 is a half hour longer than Wick 1, and the stuffing sticks out.

name: Matthew Rozsa
review: While "John Wick: Chapter 3 - Parabellum" is an easy movie to recommend, it must be added that it's a hard movie to love.

name: Christian Toto
review: The action franchise hits its "Fast & Furious"-like stride, assuming wanton killings are your style.

name: Dustin Chase
review: John Wick 3  might be the first non-stop action film that simultaneously manages to be boring due to its extensive repetitious nature.

name: Sonny Bunch
review: Great action masks a meditation on the natural order.

name: Rohan Naahar
review: As hyper-stylised Neo-noir action threequels go, it's damn near a masterpiece - breathtakingly beautiful to look at, mythologically dense, and featuring the best action set pieces since Mission: Impossible - Fallout.

name: Doug Jamieson
review: Cemented by its leading man and terrific supporting cast, the third film in this sleeper-hit series is blissful escapism at its finest. To be blunt, it's an absolute bloody riot.

name: Linda and Al Lerner
review: There is so much murder and it happens so fast that you're left with admiration for the dance rather than what is happening to the dancers. You have to give credit for the extraordinarily creative ways to fend off Wick's constant flow of enemies.

name: Tom Santilli
review: The world of John Wick exponentially expands in its 3rd chapter, but the more we learn about this organized criminal underworld the less interesting it, and our hero, becomes.

name: Ruth Maramis
review: It's an action franchise where absurdity is the norm given the sheer invincibility of the hero. The ultra-stylized action gets so overblown it's cartoonish, but THAT is precisely the appeal of John Wick movies.

name: Jamie East
review: I can't imagine anyone going to see this not knowing what kind of thing to expect - so therefore I can't imagine anyone not having the time of their lives.

name: Brian Viner
review: Reeves gives a charismatic lead performance, tearing another page from the Clint Eastwood manual of laconic hard men.

name: Matthew Passantino
review: "John Wick: Chapter 3 - Parabellum" will likely have you fist-pumping in your seat, but it had me checking my watch.

name: Sam Adams
review: The best way to watch isn't with oohs and aahhs. It's with laughter, savoring the beauty and the absurdity of each elaborate spectacle. Each movement is a joke, and death is the ultimate punchline.

name: Luke Goodsell
review: Parabellum continues to deliver the kind of fight choreography that serves as an antidote to the CGI slickness of other action spectacles, but it seems unlikely that the creative team can successfully lap the same premise for much longer.

name: Beth Accomando
review: John Wick 3 is not a great film in terms of the ideas it explores but it is a work that features absolute perfection in the execution of its action scenes and the way it pushes the envelope in terms of what stunt performers can do.

name: Jonathan Roberts
review: The longer and clearer the fight scenes are, the more daylight is let in on the magic. That said, it is still fun. Reeves does his thing, Ian McShane works his roguish charm at an Olympic standard and we get more Lance Reddick.

name: Juanma Fernández París
review: The director and the scriptwriters manage to give more of a surprise turn that indicates that the saga on the big screen is not over yet. [Full Review in Spanish]

name: Dom Sinacola
review: John Wick 3 revels in its ludicrous gore without losing sight of the very real toll of such unmitigated havoc.

name: Geoffrey Macnab
review: At times, the action is so relentless it risks becoming monotonous.

name: Chris Klimek
review: The set pieces are more imaginative and daring than ever. There's a musicality and wit to the action that only the Mission: Impossible series can equal.

name: Bob Bloom
review: 'John Wick 3' is brutal, but beautiful; graceful, but violently graphic. Director Chad Stahelski is like the Sergei Eisenstein of fight sequences, and in Reeves he has found the perfect partner. ...

name: Jake Wilson
review: Is there is anything of substance to hang on to amid these endless reflections? What is undeniable, certainly, is Reeves' dedication to his role, which suggests the enthusiasm of a puppy wanting to please.

name: Joe Morgenstern
review: Mixed feelings about the violence are inescapable... Still, there's nothing iffy about the best action stuff in John Wick: Chapter 3 - Parabellum, although the film runs out of fresh ideas toward the end.

name: Chase Whale
review: What started as a new action movie from The Matrix star Keanu Reeves, has now turned into one of the greatest action franchises in film history. John Wick movies will be watched and talked about long after you and I are gone.

name: Frank Swietek
review: A bloated chapter in the saga, one that proves that more can actually mean less...overkill sets in, in every sense.

name: James Clay
review: Despite carnage being the main selling point, "John Wick: Chapter 3″ is the most intriguing when we get the chance to see the mechanics of how this criminal underworld operates.

name: Sean Collier
review: The scope and breadth of the choreography and the inventiveness of the set pieces are remarkable.

name: Mark Dujsik
review: John Wick: Chapter 3 - Parabellum possesses enough new ideas -- in terms of its world and John's methods of dispatching foes -- to remain exciting.

name: J Hurtado
review: This is an action lover's dream and I hope I never wake up.

name: Eric Melin
review: A total contradiction. It sets a new bar for action in the moment, but suffers cumulatively for it. As its universe grows larger, it gets less compelling, and the screenplay creates all kinds of problems for Wick that it can't satisfactorily resolve.

name: Jeremy Jahns
review: John Wick: Chapter Three delivers what you want in a John Wick movie... Better than [Chapter Two], but not as good as [the first].

name: Dominic Corry
review: It's a more brutal and violent affair than the often elegant Chapter 2, but that doesn't feel accidental, and the set pieces are nothing less than transcendent.

name: Ryan Porter
review: Check your grounded Harrison Ford-era action ideals at the door: this is the biggest and most bonkers John Wick yet.

name: Charles Koplinski
review: "Parabellum" delivers the goods, stumbles at the end.

name: Richard Jordan
review: The film incredibly manages to up the action ante -- no mean feat given the blistering set-pieces of the first two films -- and dishes up a series of increasingly jaw-dropping stunts that are, as always, captured operatically.

name: Pamela Powell
review: In the decade-long career of reviewing films, I cannot recall a more disturbingly grotesque display of violence.

name: Brian Lowry
review: [It] certainly follows that script -- or rather, lack of one -- delivering adrenaline-fueled thrills, before fatigue creeps into the unrelenting mayhem about halfway through.

name: Jeannette Catsoulis
review: The violence has been supercharged, and so has the virtuosity. At a certain point, though, the carnage becomes deadening, its consequences no more than soulless tableaus of damage that encourage disengagement.

name: Kyle Smith
review: So the writing is video-game thin. But if you take the film in the spirit in which it is intended, as a series of elaborately choreographed set pieces, it's thrilling enough, at least at the beginning and the end.

name: Christopher Lloyd
review: The once raw stunts-and-guns franchise is clearly showing middle age, with more CGI cheats and overlong fights. But it's still damn fun.

name: Chris Hunneysett
review: Parabellum comes from a latin phrase meaning 'prepare for war'. Well, you can't say this bloody and frequently brilliant episode doesn't warn you of what to expect.

name: Roger Tennis
review: Buckets of bloody gore and an endless stream of kick-butt battles fuel another satisfying entry in this killer series.

name: Paul Whitington
review: It's a bit long perhaps, and we could have done without much of the last half hour, but those fights scenes really are exceptional, astonishing feats of choreography and editing that make mortal combat look like art.

name: Marc Savlov
review: Any initially out-of-nowhere action franchise that can maintain this bedeviling level of elaborate and exhilarating complexity is a welcome addition/addiction to an otherwise musclebound genre currently in thrall to the Marvel-ous.

name: Barry Hertz
review: No-name assassins are still stupid enough to think they can kill Wick, and Wick is still happy to prove them wrong.

name: Nick Johnston
review: Parabellum forgoes most of its storytelling smarts to deliver the most pulse-pounding, intense action sequences that the series has ever seen. And honestly? It's a damn good trade-off.

name: Brad Keefe
review: "John Wick 3" often feels like an arthouse Steven Seagal flick, and I mean that as praise. It starts at hyper-violent and over-the-top and then sees where it can go from there.

name: Leigh Paatsch
review: Against all odds, the John Wick franchise will never be down for the count as long as it keeps upping the ante.

name: Matthew Turner
review: A thrilling, inventive and beautifully directed action threequel that doesn't drag for moment of its 130-minute running time.

name: James Berardinelli
review: I'd love to say that fans of the first two movies will love this one, but I fall into that group and I was a little disappointed by this outing.

name: Gary Thompson
review: The goal for director Stahelski is escalating violence and bloody chaos, pushed to the point of the preposterous and beyond.

name: Michael Phillips
review: This one's the best of the three so far.

name: Laura Clifford
review: It's hard to imagine just how franchise director Chad Stahelski and star Reeves are going to top Chapter 3, the most action-packed and outrageously violent of the series to date...That the film is such a treat for the eyes is gilding the lily.

name: Matthew Thrift
review: An astonishing spectacle of action and staging.

name: Cath Clarke
review: As per the two previous films, Stahelski cranks up the body count with a string of fight sequences so balletic you might forget you're watching violence - until Reeves sinks a knife into a man's eye.

name: Peter Gray
review: It's difficult to harbour any ill will against the film as both a continuing chapter in a larger story and a strikingly shot balletic thriller on its own accord.

name: Cary Darling
review: "John Wick: Chapter 3 - Parabellum" is by far the most entertaining of the series, a film that noisily fits the definition of a summer popcorn movie and makes no pretense of having any higher goals.

name: Louisa Moore
review: Finally, an American action movie that deserves to be mentioned in the same conversation as The Raid and The Raid 2.

name: Sean P. Means
review: The fights here don't have the same out-of-the-box charm of the original - you only get to make a first impression once - they are brimming with eye-popping spectacle.

name: Simon Miraudo
review: The John Wick brand is so strong, his enemies are now introducing themselves as fans.

name: Amie Simon
review: Bottom line: Parabellum is a little clunkier and a little campier than the previous two films, but it's still HELLA FUN and I will be happy watching Keanu do this until I die.

name: Anthony O'Connor
review: Combined with a spare script containing minimal dialogue, the film is a beautifully choreographed bullet ballet of shattered glass and broken bones.

name: Soren Andersen
review: It's all pretty silly, but the way "Parabellum" keeps topping itself and then topping the toppings makes the picture eminently watchable. It's a guilty summertime-movie pleasure for sure.

name: Michael O'Sullivan
review: "John Wick: Chapter 3 - Parabellum" is neither subtle nor thoughtful. It is, arguably, a nasty piece of work. But, like its hero, it knows what it does best, and it does it - however paradoxical this may sound - beautifully.

name: Allison Shoemaker
review: It's a thrilling, surprising, often funny film, centered on a terrific performance.

name: Jennifer Heaton
review: Parabellum does not disappoint in offering yet another dose of ultraviolent goodness.

name: Preston Barta
review: 'John Wick: Chapter 3' is a beautiful symphony of violence and mayhem. It's some of the greatest action you'll ever see and it'll, no doubt, have everyone in your theater moaning like Meg Ryan in the famous scene from 'When Harry Met Sally.'

name: Ray Pride
review: Generous hallucination... Tossed, torn, noosed, dragged, stabbed, shot, shot, crotch-bit, machine-gunned, hand-axed, saber-sliced, face-crushed, shot, burnt, bullied, horse-kicked, catapulted, subjected to sustained knife fracas and shot.

name: Grant Watson
review: It is the action that is the draw here. Gunfights on horseback. Sword fights on motorcyles. People throwing knives at each other in a shop full of antique knives.

name: Daniel Rutledge
review: While there may be less headshots in this third outing, the inventiveness has been notched up and it's a bloody good time.

name: Brian Orndorf
review: Plenty of eye-opening moments featuring blunt force trauma, and while Stahelski has some difficulty knowing when to cry uncle, he's more than ready to showcase an exquisite display of stunt work.

name: Josh Larsen
review: ...less about Wick and more about the grandiosity of the violence.

name: Jen Yamato
review: "Parabellum" bursts with the series' usual sleek and squishy top-notch action, and the healthy dose of the winking humor that breaks Wick and his cronies out of the bounds of the genre.

name: John Lui
review: In its third iteration, the franchise is showing its age.

name: Graeme Tuckett
review: I still enjoyed pretty much every minute of John Wick 3, but there are enough fumbles here to suggest a franchise that is cashing in, when it should know when to quit.

name: Johnny Oleksinski
review: The plot of "John Wick 3" won't surprise you, but the movie will.

name: Chris Barsanti
review: The action choreography is as brutal as you expect, though the repetition in style from the first two films makes the effect less surprising.

name: Peter Travers
review: You can wait around and hope for a bigger, badder burst of action fireworks than John Wick 3, but you'd be kidding yourself. The wow factor is off the charts.

name: MaryAnn Johanson
review: Modern noir god Keanu Reeves again stalks a fantasy(ish) world of exhausting, inventive violence. But this time, the curtain is drawn back on the sham of seeming orderliness in its world (and ours).

name: Nigel Andrews
review: The film is truly terrible unless you think its maxed-up minimalism is truly, weirdly, metaphysically avant-garde.

name: Jonathan W. Hickman
review: Grotesque and sometimes beautiful, an exquisitely crafted series of impossible action sequences make "Chapter 3" necessary viewing. And the expansion of the Wick mythology hints at something even bigger on the horizon.

name: Travis Hopson
review: The previous films were so effortlessly magnificent and bold beyond their simple framing that John Wick 3's obvious attempts to be epic are exactly what keep it from being so.

name: Matt Oakes
review: It's hardcore porn with guns and blades and anyone who's here for this third John Wick movie has knowingly come to wank at its altar.

name: David Sims
review: The series remains the most reliable purveyor of high-stakes, onscreen combat around, a franchise that hasn't yet been tarnished by its ongoing success.

name: Rafer Guzman
review: Reeves retains his crown as the king of ultraviolent action with this solid threequel.

name: Julian Roman
review: Action junkies are going to blissfully overdose. John Wick: Chapter 3 - Parabellum ramps up every facet of the ultra-stylized violence. It is a tsunami of gunplay, martial arts, and literally mind-blowing action.

name: Jeffrey Lyles
review: It's hard not to take in the carnage and think some of the luster has faded from the franchise, but this features some of the series' best off the wall death and destruction.

name: Andrew Parker
review: The latest entry into the best action franchise going today continues the series' upward trajectory into fresh, exciting, but potentially top heavy territory.

name: Hope Madden
review: Inside of 10 minutes it was clear that this is the best film of the trilogy.

name: Karen Krizanovich
review: Wick 3 is jaw-droppingly violent, hilarious and surprising. It's also a hell-of-a lesson in cool.

name: Linda Marric
review: Relentless, exhilarating and utterly bonkers.

name: Douglas Davidson
review: ... Parabellum delivers all the brutal, bone-crunching, Gun Fu audiences desire as the story continues to follow the beleaguered Mr. Wick on his journey through Hell to find redemption.

name: Katie Walsh
review: Does "John Wick: Chapter Three - Parabellum" break the formula? It most certainly does not. Director Chad Stahelski wouldn't dare. But you almost wish he would.

name: Roger Moore
review: Raises the bar on "relentless."

name: Matthew Toomey
review: In keeping with the style of the previous two flicks, director Chad Stahelski makes the film "stand out" with colourful production design and a strong editing.

name: Larushka Ivan-Zadeh
review: The John Wick movies stand apart due to their bone-crunchingly 'real' punch-ups and breath-stopping choreography.

name: David Ehrlich
review: Giddy, exhausting, and breathtakingly violent.

name: Jim Slotek
review: Stahelski and Reeves have taken the fluid action of the series to a point of "how are they going to top that last insane thing they did?" And there's an imagination at work that's straight out of Looney Tunes.

name: Harry Guerin
review: Although the action scenes are again superbly choreographed by returning director Chad Stahelski, his third time behind the lens has far more teflon than tension.

name: Barbara VanDenburgh
review: "The Matrix" is in its DNA, and like "The Matrix," "John Wick" elevates action not by apologizing for it but embodying it, and embedding in its thrills meditations on the nature of existence.

name: David Edelstein
review: The movie should by rights be a "Wow!" But it feels bloated, self-conscious, and pretentious, with long waits between its few dazzling fights.

name: Peter Sobczynski
review: A work of pop cinema so blissfully, albeit brutally, entertaining that you come out of it feeling even more resentful of its multiplex neighbors for not making a similar effort.

name: Peter Hartlaub
review: It's like combining the anything-can-happen excitement of playing a slot machine, with the grace of a ballet, and the prolonged and escalating violence of a good gladiator battle.

name: Joshua Rothkopf
review: Director Chad Stahelski is a fight-scene Fosse and Reeves is his Gwen Verdon: Parabellum takes the hall-of-mirrors high style of the second film and pushes it into overdrive.

name: Scott Mendelson
review: A rip-roaring (and visually beautiful) action movie that plays like a terrific video game come to life while also dealing with the whole "Why should we care if John survives?" question.

name: Dorian Parks
review: John Wick 3 is truly a non stop thrill ride from start to finish.

name: Todd Gilchrist
review: Kolstad and his collaborators have created a phenomenal ensemble of actors to populate this stylish, intriguing criminal underworld...

name: Kirsten Acuna
review: "'Parabellum' is an immensely enjoyable watch with a small lull in the middle that should keep fans excited and ready to come back for a fourth film."

name: Nate Adams
review: Just when you think this series can't build or, rather, bring more precision and stylistic action sequences to the medium, "John Wick Chapter 3: Parabellum" almost rewrites the status quo of what action blockbusters can be.

name: Ed Travis
review: The John Wick films are the premiere action franchise on the planet right now.

name: Sarah Cartland
review: Outlandish, pitiless, witty, madly entertaining, and like its predecessors utterly gorgeous. Reeves is exceptional, taking Wick to the next stage of a mind-boggling journey now so extreme you wonder what he can do next (usually right before he does it).

name: Brent Goldman
review: John Wick: Chapter 3 - Parabellum is the best film of the series so far, and proves there is no better action series this decade.

name: Rendy Jones
review: Parabellum continues the franchise's incredible winning streak, solidifying John Wick as being the greatest action franchise in cinematic history, bar none.

name: Richard Roeper
review: It's a hard-R live action cartoon, and it is superb, wall-to-wall action entertainment.

name: Dan Murrell
review: The action is as spectacular as ever, but I do think that John Wick is showing signs of fatigue, both as a character and as a franchise.

name: Ja-Quan Greene
review: Another gloriously violent outing for the world's finest super assassin.

name: Andrea Chase
review: PARABELLUM works beyond being short on story with its stylish, sumptuous visuals and Reeves himself. He is a minimalist in front of the camera, making for a pointed contrast to the other elements in which he works

name: Ignatiy Vishnevetsky
review: But its artistic ambitions-some might even call them pretensions-and expanded cast of offbeat characters would all be for naught if the movie weren't also chock full of ecstatic set pieces.

name: Jordan Ruimy
review: However visually stimulating it may be, this third chapter in the series barely shakes off the overall sense of deja vu. And yet, if this 'Wick' lacks the fresh bite of the second chapter, its barrage of choreographic chaos is noteworthy enough.

name: Jordan Raup
review: A balletic, radiant, and relentless feat of action filmmaking, captured with the kind of clear-eyed, pleasure-filled elegance reminiscent of Jacques Demy.

name: Perri Nemiroff
review: John Wick 3 is wild! The series has had high quality combat throughout but the sequences the team pulls off here are downright nuts. A perfect example of why we need a stunts category at the Oscars.

name: Robert Kojder
review: At this point, the John Wick movies are becoming a new drug, so go get your fix. Prepare for more than war, prepare for constant exhilarating anarchy

name: Kat Hughes
review: From the explosive opening, to the epic finale, John Wick Parabellum is an adrenaline charged assault to the senses. A cacophony of bullets, broken glass and samurai swords, it launches everything in the arsenal to send the franchise out on a high.

name: Mike Ryan
review: The best film of the John Wick franchise so far

name: Grace Randolph
review: The best case yet for a stunt category at the Oscars! Wall to wall action, you literally won't be able to take your eyes off the screen.

name: Griffin Schiller
review: Three incredibly rock-solid entries in, there's no jumping the gun, John Wick has confidently cemented itself as one of the great action franchises.

name: Robert Daniels
review: John Wick: Chapter 3 - Parabellem...is another exceptional hit from Keanu Reeves, and a bone-crushing triumph.

name: JimmyO
review: John Wick 3 is an ass-kicking, ramped-up thrill ride with amazing characters that continues to prove that director Stahelski and Reeves make a perfect cinematic partnership.

name: Andrew Barker
review: As it stretches beyond the two-hour mark the film becomes, to use a loaded term, desensitizing.

name: Clint Worthington
review: Fight sequences, after all, are just another kind of dance - which might make Reeves the Mikhail Baryshnikov of shooting people in the face.

name: Alissa Wilkinson
review: Whatever it lacks in narrative intelligence it makes up abundantly in visual moxie, and in a medium that is first and foremost visual, that's what makes something great.

name: Aaron Neuwirth
review: There's so much great variety in all the shootouts, fist fights, motorcycle chases, and horse chases that it's hard not to applaud all the work that went into setting up so many successful set pieces...

name: Jake Coyle
review: With a seamless mix of CGI and stunt work, Stahelski fluidly choreographs ballets of bullets and endless violent encounters across a grim cityscape.

name: Karen Han
review: Throw a horse chase, a Villainess-esque motorcycle-katana fight, and a healthy dose of electro-Vivaldi into the mix, and it's just enough to keep the Wick formula working - and keep an audience wanting more.

name: Kevin Harley
review: If you thought Wick 2's turbo-powered takedowns could not be out-powered, think on: intermittent stumbles aside, Parabellum swiftly asserts itself as 2019's actioner to beat.

name: Nick De Semlyen
review: Combat-heavy pulp of the highest order, this is the most enjoyably over-the-top entry so far. Where else can you get samurai dogs and a Tarkovsky reference?

name: Chris Nashawaty
review: I don't mean to give the impression that John Wick 3 is anything grander than a gorgeously choreographed, gratuitously violent action movie. But as gorgeously choreographed, gratuitously violent action movies go, it's high art.

name: Tim Robey
review: As relentless action sequels go, Parabellum stands comparison with The Raid 2, delivering a meaty set piece every reel or so, and not holding back with the flailing, mechanised slaughter.

name: Jim Vejvoda
review: The action is bloody and over-the-top and the emotional throughline remains solid as we follow John Wick on his journey to either save his skin or die trying.

name: William Bibbiani
review: Had the potential to be one of the best action movies ever made. Instead, it's just super badass. (We should all have such problems.)

name: Brian Truitt
review: It's almost a karmic answer to everything else in the action-movie genre, where there's usually a distinct lack of responsibility in the wanton violence: In the "Wick"-verse, a bloody action usually leads to much more trouble later.

name: John DeFore
review: An epic of choreographed mayhem that expands the Wickiverse in mostly pleasing ways, it is destined to satisfy fans of this surprise-hit franchise: If its ludicrous aspects bug you, what the hell are you doing here?

name: Brent Hankins
review: The marriage of brutal hand-to-hand combat and impossibly precise gunplay have been franchise staples, and John Wick: Chapter 3 takes these elements to incredible heights with some of the most flat-out insane action choreography ever seen.

name: Sherin Nicole
review: Parabellum is the movie equivalent of a 3D experience at the amusement park...you'll gleefully line up when it ends--just so this movie can fry your brain one more time. Everything about it hurtles Parabellum to the peak of the assassin movie sub-genre.

name: Edward Douglas
review: Reeves has finally made another action movie on par with The Matrix.

name: Chris Evangelista
review: John Wick 3 is a bone-cracking, horse-kicking, dog-biting, book-smashing, ax-throwing action masterpiece.

name: Robert Abele
review: The set-up for a "Chapter 4" is a sign that the creators have an extended stay on their minds, even though they might want to check out while this uniquely enjoyable violent fantasy still feels like an action holiday.

name: Courtney Howard
review: An eye-popping, jaw-dropping, show-stopping next chapter that extends the world-building beautifully, whilst assigning meaningful resonance to the character-driven action.

name: Sean Mulvihill
review: This is easily going to be the year's best action film, and if anything comes along and surpasses it I shall kneel before the filmmakers and pledge my fealty.

name: Matt Donato
review: John Wick: Chapter 3 - Parabellum features the same cyclical franchise storytelling, but as executed thus far, further evolves action with newfound freshness and invigoration that ensures John Wick is Hollywood's most reliable action star.
